posts.name: Ankur Desai
posts.cooked: Is the limelight moving with the shooter or does that stay stationary, also I would suggest using robot pose to calculate distance to speaker and then collecting a bunch of data, putting it into a graph and finding a line of best fit. The shooter angle is not linear, so you have to collect data so that you have an actual good equation to calculate the angle.

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: the limelight is stationary, how can i get the robot pose, i need the tracking 3d of apriltag right?

Strictly speaking, you don’t need to estimate the robot pose. Our team uses a bunch of LL measurements then maps them to angle setpoints, like so:

This is stored in our constants file, which is then fed into an interopolatingTreeMap in the constructor of our shooter:

you can put in a distance (or in your case, a Ta from the limelight), and then get an angle like so:

This method does require a bit of experimentation to find good values from multiple distances, but once it’s tuned you shouldn’t need to change it much.

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: u dont know any easyiest way to do this, bcs i cant do anything very complex, i dont have a lot of time to do a complex code

You could try some equation like MinAngle - 1/(Multiplier*ta+constant)

The above code really isn’t anything too complicated, though. The last two bits you can essentially copy+paste. The only hard part is testing different angles for different Ta’s and then putting those values into the map. If you are confused about anything, I can help/explain.

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: if u can explain for me, bcs i read your code above, and i dont understand anything, this line what u share in this reply is very similar of my code now, but isn’t working with the same way what i want.

There was a typo with my equation, it should be MinAngle - 1/(Multiplier*ta+constant). Here is a graph I made on desmos to help explain, the y-axis is the angle and the x-axis is the Ta you give the code/equation:

image 1381×947 80.3 KB

image 1381×947 80.3 KB

image 1381×947 80.3 KB

The red line is your current equation. The blue line is the corrected equation above, and the orange graph is an example of what the code above does. You feed points into the InterpolatingDoubleTreeMap object in wpilib, and it will draw lines in between. When you want to get a value, it will automatically return the value of the line were at the input you give it. It saves you the work of having to implement the lines-between-points yourself. The main advantage of doing it this way is that if you have issues shooting from far out, when Ta is small, you can change the code and not affect the shooting when you are close and Ta is larger.

posts.name: Frank
posts.cooked: Is it possible to use this if I want to get two values from one distance? I want to set the rpm for our top and bottom shooter wheels, which changes based on distance. Right now, I can only set one pair, but is it possible to include 2 pairs? Or would I have to do the whole thing twice, one for each shooter

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: I understand how work the equation, but i dont understand how is the implementation in the code, and the interligation with the feeded information and the graph to do the equation

Technically, you can. Wpilib offers a generalized version of interpolatingtreemap that allows you to construct it with any <Key, Value> pair as long as you provide the comparator, interpolator and inverseinterpolator.

I would recommend against doing this, though, as it would be less work and cleaner code to just have two standard InterpolatingDoubleTreeMaps. It would work the same either way.
which part of the code are you confused about?

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: the working of the interpolationgtreemap, im confused about it

Hopefully this makes it more clear!

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: i read this and try understand, i understand, but don’t know if is correct, but in my vision, this work similar a if and else, for a Ta it get a angle on the list, i understand right?

Not exactly? An interpolatingTreeMap interpolates between the values closest the the key from the left and right if the key itself is not given to it in a <key,value> pair.

Question: In the code above, what do you think LLShotMap.get(Ta) returns?

posts.name: Guilherme
posts.cooked: it returns the angle of the “list” closest of the Ta??

Nope, refer to the graph above: it takes the two values to the left and right of the given Ta, draws a line between them, and then takes the value of that line at the given Ta. This process is called a linear interpolation. You do a similar thing in your code for just two points, its just the InterpolatingDoubleTreeMap does it for multiple points.
